032package org.opengis.test;
033
034import org.opengis.geometry.DirectPosition;
035import org.opengis.referencing.operation.MathTransform;
036import org.opengis.test.referencing.TransformTestCase;
037
038
039/**
040 * The kind of calculation that produced the {@link DirectPosition}s being compared.
041 * This enumeration is expected by all {@code assertCoordinateEquals(…)} methods in the
042 * {@link TransformTestCase} class. The enumeration values are consumed by the following
043 * methods:
044 *
045 * <ul>
046 *   <li>{@link TransformTestCase#normalize(DirectPosition, DirectPosition, CalculationType)}</li>
047 *   <li>{@link ToleranceModifier#adjust(double[], DirectPosition, CalculationType)}</li>
048 * </ul>
049 *
050 * For example if a precision of 10 centimetres is requested for a map projection, then that
051 * tolerance threshold must be converted from metres to decimal degrees (approximately 1E-6°)
052 * when testing the inverse projection. This enumeration allows {@link ToleranceModifier}
053 * implementations to know when such conversion is needed.
054 *
055 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
056 * @version 3.1
057 * @since   3.1
058 */
059public enum CalculationType {
060    /**
061     * The ordinate values to compare are the result of an identity operation (a plain copy).
062     * Ordinate values are checked for strict equality.
063     */
064    IDENTITY,
065
066    /**
067     * The ordinate values to compare are the result of a direct operation performed by the
068     * {@linkplain TransformTestCase#transform transform to test}.
069     */
070    DIRECT_TRANSFORM,
071
072    /**
073     * The ordinate values to compare are the result of an
074     * {@linkplain MathTransform#inverse() inverse transform}.
075     */
076    INVERSE_TRANSFORM,
077
078    /**
079     * The numbers to compare is a column of a {@linkplain MathTransform#derivative(DirectPosition)
080     * transform derivative}. Each column of the derivative matrix is the displacement in the
081     * <em>target</em> CRS when an ordinate value in the source CRS is increased by one. Those
082     * derivative values are comparable to the target ordinate values: they use the same units
083     * in the same order. Consequently in case of doubt, implementors can use the same policy
084     * than for {@link #DIRECT_TRANSFORM}.
085     */
086    TRANSFORM_DERIVATIVE;
087
088    /**
089     * @deprecated Renamed {@link #IDENTITY}.
090     */
091    @Deprecated
092    public static final CalculationType STRICT = IDENTITY;
093}
